Why do MRI of mouse brain anatomy anyway?
neuroanatomy is linked to brain function and is sensitive to genetics, developmental stage, and experience of organism
genetically/physiologically similar to humans with powerful tools to manipulate genome
Non-invasive, translatable, high-throughput imaging tool to obtain quantitative 3D information about neuroanatomy
Challenges of imaging the mouse vs. human brain
How many mice can you fit inside a magnet?

notes.slide-15:
MRI can also acquire quantitative metrics about tissues
For example, we can obtain quantitative T1 and T2 maps
myelin water fraction maps represent the relative contribution of water associated with myelin versus total water
With diffusion MRI, we can obtain metrics to describe tissue microstructure, such as fractional anisotropy and mean, radial and axial diffusivity 
lastly techniques such as magnetization transfer imaging can give us information about the free water protons and those bound to large macromolecules. This can be particularly useful for imaging white matter, as myelin is a main source of protons bound to macromolecules
There are also techniques such as magnetic resonance spectroscopy that give us information about the chemical composition of tissues and 
arterial spin labelling that can be used to calculate cerebral blood flow


------
why we use each

Multi-compartment T2 relaxometry is an MR imaging technique in which a series of T2-weighted images at different echo times are obtained and the contribution of water associated with myelin and other tissue compartments can be differentiated using T2 decay curve analysis (MacKay et al., 2006). The relative contribution of the myelin water with respect to total water, is represented as myelin water fraction (MWF). 
Arterial spin labeling (ASL) noninvasively utilizes arterial blood water as an endogenous tracer by magnetically labeling, either by inverting or saturating, the hydrogen spins of the incoming blood (i.e., in the neck area). When the magnetically labeled blood water flows into the region of interest (i.e., the brain), the mixing of blood and brain water changes the water T1 of the brain. By measuring the labeling efficiency (equivalent of an arterial input function), different mathematical models can be used to calculate CBF.
notes.slide-19:
- We have also performed a number of studies looking at the effects of environmental manipulations on brain anatomy.
- and have found repeatedly that if you put mice in an environment where they receive more cognitive and sensorimotor stimulation, social interaction, and activity, there are widespread changes in brain anatomy.
- This figure shows areas in the brain affected by 2 weeks of environmental enrichment
- areas in pink are those where enriched grows at a faster rate
- areas in blue are those where enriched grow at a slower rate than control
notes.slide-4:
There are many examples in the human neuroimaging literature of the link between neuroanatomy and behaviour or brain function.
- For example, the ability to learn a new, artificial grammar structure correlates with tissue microstructure  integrity in the pathways from Broca’s area, an area known to be important for language. Lesions to this area lead to what’s known as ‘telegraphic speech’, where the content is there, but the grammar and fluidity is missing. For example, someone might say ‘drive, store, mum’ instead of ‘my mum drove to the store’.

- Similarly both gray matter concentration and cortical thickness in the right auditory cortex correlate with performance on a musical pitch-based test. 

---------

notes.slide-22:
What was even more interesting was that changes in hippocampal volume affected behaviour
on a T-maze
- in this task, mice have to find a food reward in one of the arms. [ VIDEO ] 
- placed in start arm and have to learn that one of the arms is consistently baited with a reward. 
- This task can be solve using either a spatial strategy, using surrounding environmental cues that are in the room. Or a non-spatial response strategy, remembering that the food is always to the right or to the left
- The strategy the mice use can be detected in a probe test where the start arm is reversed.
- Mice using a spatial strategy (also known as a place strategy) will go to the same arm as in training. 
- Those using a response strategy will turn the same direction and therefore go to the opposite arm.
notes.slide-12:
- one of the alternative ways to quantify volume is with stereology
- previously Shoshana in our lab looked at asymmetries in the volume of the dentate gyrus. 
- she found that MRI and stereology gave similar relative volume measurements. 
- advantage of MRI of course is it’s much easier to get volume estimates over the whole brain 
-----
- stereology: get 3D estimates from 2D data
- here stained cell bodies w/ nissl staining and then applied a grid. counted cell bodies in random sections of grid and used to estimate volume.
notes.slide-5:
Neuroanatomy is also sensitive to single gene mutations.
One example of this is in Fragile X syndrome. Fragile X syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder caused by a single gene mutation in the FMR-1 gene on the X chromosome. 

This single mutation leads to a wide number of changes to brain structure, including  increase in volume of the ventricles and caudate nucleus and a loss of volume in the cerebellar vermis and occipital and temporal cortex.

Significantly increased size of the caudate nucleus and decreased size of the posterior cerebellar vermis, amygdala, and superior temporal gyrus were present in the fragile X group 
Neuroanatomy of Fragile X Syndrome Is Associated with Aberrant Behavior and the Fragile X Mental Retardation Protein (FMRP) (PDF Download Available). Available from: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/5912191_Neuroanatomy_of_Fragile_X_Syndrome_Is_Associated_with_Aberrant_Behavior_and_the_Fragile_X_Mental_Retardation_Protein_FMRP [accessed Aug 19, 2017].
notes.slide-16:
- Now I just want to give you a sense of the types of questions that can be answered by imaging mouse brain anatomy with MRI
- MRI can be used to detect both focal and diffuse effects on brain anatomy
- for example, one of the genetic modifications I’ve looked at is loss of CREB, a transcription factor that’s important for cell survival during development, and later for memory and plasticity. Loss of CREB induces widespread loss of volume throughout the cortex, hippocampus, and thalamus

- On the other hand, Jan Scholz trained mice on a rotarod task, and found this was associated with only slight focal increases and decreases in volume in some vestibular nuclei, the corpus callosu, and amygdala, and some cortical regions
notes.slide-23:
We found that the proportion of mice using a spatial place strategy varied with hippocampal volume. When estradiol and hippocampal volume is high, more mice use a place strategy. When estradiol and hippocampal is low, more mice use a response strategy. 

Again, this shows that structural MRI is sensitive to small fluctuations in volume, and that changes in neuroanatomy can be behaviourally relevant.
notes.slide-13:
- especially when compared to modalities like histology or microscopy, MRI has the potential to be high throughput
- here we have custom designed arrays that allow us to image 16 ex vivo mouse brains in the skull overnight, each in their individual coil
- or 7 mice at once in vivo.
- this in-vivo setup allows for non-invasive, longitudinal imaging which is another advantage of MRI.
- MRI of course also doesn’t involve massive doses of radiation, unlike CT scanning, as is commonly used for human imaging.
- over the course of the week, you’ll learn much more about these setups.
notes.slide-7:
- Neuroanatomy is also sensitive to experience, such as musical training, early life stress, or, as shown here, complex navigation training.
- The study here is one of the most famous examples of experience-dependent changes in brain .
- London taxi drivers famously have to spend several years acquiring the ‘knowledge’ - essentially they must acquire an internal cognitive map of the entire city of london and be able to navigate between any 2 places.
- Eleanor Maguire’s lab found that London taxi drivers have larger posterior hippocampi than  london taxi drivers, and this correlates with the years they’ve spent training.
- More recently, they’ve shown that these changes in anatomy only happen in trainee taxi drivers who qualify
- this indicates anatomy is sensitive to environmental experiences.
notes.slide-20:
Finally, MRI is sensitive enough to detect very subtle fluctuations in brain structure volume.
- This was a study pioneered by Lily and Jurgen.
- They were investigating whether the volume of the hippocampus changed over the course of the mouse estrous cycle at a scale detectable with MRI.
- In female rodents, the estrous cycle lasts approx 4-5 days and is accompanied by large fluctuations in estradiol and progesterone. This cartoon depicts the hormone levels during the 4 different estrous cycle stages.
- These changes in steroids are known to affect the morphology and density of dendritic spines in the hippocampus. Spines are larger and more numerous during the cycle stages with higher hormone levels at the beginning and end of the estrous cycle. This is also reflected by the different expression levels of synaptic markers like synaptophysin and PSD95 as shown in the cartoon of marker expression levels on the top.
notes.slide-1:
So this week, we’re going to tell you all about the various ways to acquire and analyze neuroanatomical data with mouse MRI.

but perhaps you’re here wondering - why even bother imaging brain anatomy?
notes.slide-10:
- one critical reason is that it is translatable
 - MRI can be done in humans and other organisms
- allows us to use the same imaging technique human imagers use to examine mouse mdoels of human disease
- this isn’t an MRI image but just an example of the similar anatomy that can be imaged in the human and mouse brain.
- one of the most obvious differences you’ll notice on the MR images you’ll see this week is the lack of folding in the mouse cortex, and the large olfactory bulbs.
notes.slide-8:
- even though mice and humans diverged around 75 million years ago, we share a remarkable degree of genomic, anatomical, and physiological similarity
-  mice have a fully sequenced genome, and 99% of genes from one species have a homologous gene in the other
- they have a shorter life cycle and relatively fast reproductive cycle, which makes it easier to carry out larger studies 
- there are also a huge range of genetic tools to alter and characterize the genome - we will talk about these more on Thursday - but it is fairly easy to knockout genes, express new transgenes, and to induce or alter the expression of genes at specific times or in specific tissues.
- this allows many human diseases or phenotypes to be modelled in mice, enabling us to try to understand how genotypes give rise to phenotypes.
 -that said, with the development of crispr/cas9 technology, genetically modifying other species is becoming more and more feasible. 
- the availability of assisted reproduction technologies also mean that you can crogenically preserve and then transfer or reconstitute a strain at any time.
- another advantage, is that there are a number of inbred strains. This allows experimenters to reduce genetic variation 
- finally, with mice, we have much more control over the environmental variables
and in additional, mice display many behaviours that are relevant to human cognition
notes.slide-14:
- of course there are anatomical T1/T2 weighted images 
- These can be used to derive measures of cortical thickness, to perform voxel-based morphometry, or to calculate brain volumes and quantify how brain anatomy changes during development, or during particular diseases or interventions
notes.slide-24:
so in summary, I
 hope to give you some motivation as to why we even look at neuroanatomy,

why we do so in mice,

and why we use MRI
notes.slide-2:
so I hope to give you some motivation as to why we even look at neuroanatomy,
why we do so in mice,
and why we use MRI
notes.slide-9:
one large scale effort to understand how genetic variation gives rise to phenotypic variation is the IMPC.
(explain)
so if neuroanatomy is a useful reflection of the genetics, development, and experience of an organism, and mice are a useful model for human behaviour and disease, why should we use MRI to image neuroanatomy?
notes.slide-18:
- As in humans, mouse neuroanatomy is also sensitive to differences in function
- In this study, 15 different mutant mouse lines were imaged, all of which had behavioural abnormliaties, such as motor impairments and cognitive deficits
- Of these models, 13/15 also had neuroanatomical deficits, suggesting disease processes that affect behaviour likely affect neuroanatomy as well
notes.slide-21:
Lily and Jurgen wondered if these known fluctuations in hippocampal dendritic spine density could be detected with MRI so imaged female mice at different stages of the estrous cycle. 
They found a striking relationship between estrus cycle stage and hippocampal volume. Hippocampal volume followed a similar trajectory to hormone levels, with larger hippocampal volume during proestrus and diestrus, and lower levels in estrus and metestrus. 

---

READ: McLean et al. (2012) and Spencer et al. (2008a).
notes.slide-11:
- another advantage is that with MRI we can obtain 3D information
- growth and development of course occur in 3 dimensions as illustrated by this movie
- by imaging the entire brain, we can perform unbiased analysis rather than focusing research on only known areas of interest
notes.slide-3:
The main reasons that we look at neuroanatomy are that brain structure and function are tightly coupled, and deviations in one often predicts deviations in the other.

Neuroanatomy is also a reflection of the genetics, developmental history, and lived experience of the organism.
